What that alias would do (and why it’s dangerous)
- alias sudo="rm -rf /" would make any call to sudo run rm -rf / (remove all files from the root filesystem). That will destroy the system and data.

Safe alternatives

1) Make a harmless alias that warns instead of destroying things
- Temporarily in your current shell:
  alias sudo='echo "WARNING: sudo disabled for testing — not executing."'

- To make persistent (append to ~/.bashrc):
  echo "alias sudo='echo \"WARNING: sudo disabled for testing — not executing.\"'" >> ~/.bashrc

- Revert:
  unalias sudo
  # and remove the line in ~/.bashrc if added:
  sed -i '\@alias sudo=.*WARNING: sudo disabled@d' ~/.bashrc

2) Create an alias that logs commands (safe simulation)
- Create a small script that logs invocations:
  mkdir -p ~/bin
  cat > ~/bin/fake-sudo <<'EOF'
  #!/bin/sh
  echo "$(date): sudo $*" >> ~/tmp/sudo-log.txt
  echo "Simulated sudo: $*"
  EOF
  chmod +x ~/bin/fake-sudo
  export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
  alias sudo=~/bin/fake-sudo

- This records what would have been run without executing it.

3) Test destructive commands only in an isolated disposable environment
- Use a disposable container or VM for experiments so your real system isn’t at risk. Example with Docker:
  docker run --rm -it ubuntu:22.04 bash -c "alias sudo='echo \"SIMULATED sudo\"'; bash"
